title: 114_s2971
content: The "National Urban Search and Rescue Response System Act of 2016" is an amendment to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. It defines key terms like Administrator, Agency, Hazard, and Nonemployee System member. The National Urban Search and Rescue Response System Act of 2016 defines key terms like System member, participating agency, sponsoring agency, and System. A System member is an individual not employed by a sponsoring agency or participating agency. A participating agency is a State or local government, nonprofit organization, or private organization that has an agreement with a sponsoring agency. A sponsoring agency is a State or local government that sponsors a task force designated by the Administrator. The System refers to the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System administered under this section. The Administrator administers the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System, providing standardized search and rescue resources to assist States and local governments in responding to hazards. Task forces designated by the Administrator participate in the System, with each task force having a sponsoring agency determined by the Administrator. The Administrator administers the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System, with task forces designated to participate. Each task force has a sponsoring agency, which enters agreements with participating agencies and other individuals for their involvement. The Administrator may appoint System members into Federal service for participation in exercises, disaster response activities, and training events without following certain civil service laws. The Administrator can appoint System members into Federal service for exercises, disaster response, and training without following certain civil service laws. The appointments do not affect other authorities of the Administrator under the Act, and System members are not considered U.S. employees for purposes outside of specific provisions in this section. The Administrator can make payments to the sponsoring agency of a task force to reimburse employers for compensation paid to System members during their service. The Administrator can appoint System members into Federal service for exercises, disaster response, and training without following certain civil service laws. Payments can be made to the sponsoring agency of a task force to reimburse employers for compensation paid to System members during their service. System members appointed into Federal service under subsection (f)(1) may be eligible for reimbursement of costs incurred by their employer, only if the costs exceed what would have been incurred without the appointment. Payment directly from the Agency is not allowed during this period. In case of personal injury, illness, disability, or death, System members appointed under subsection (f)(1) are covered. System members appointed under subsection (f)(1) may be eligible for benefits under subchapter I of chapter 81 of title 5, United States Code, in case of injury, illness, disability, or death. They must elect benefits if entitled to receive benefits from both the federal government and a State or local government for the same incident. System members must elect benefits under subchapter I of chapter 81 of title 5, United States Code, if they are entitled to benefits from both the federal government and a State or local government for the same incident. The election of benefits must be made within 1 year of the injury, illness, disability, or death, and is irrevocable unless otherwise provided by law. The Administrator will reimburse State or local governments for benefits received by System members. Public safety officers can still claim benefits under certain conditions. System members appointed into Federal service are considered Federal employees for liability purposes. System members who are not regular full-time employees of a sponsoring agency or participating agency are considered to have employment and reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38, United States Code. This includes rights to service in the uniformed services and procedures for assistance, enforcement, and investigation. Giving notice of service may be precluded by the necessity of appointment under this section. The necessity of appointment under this section may preclude giving notice of absence from employment for military service under section 4312(b) of title 38, United States Code. The determination of such necessity is made by the Administrator and is not subject to judicial review. System members holding valid licenses or permits are deemed to be performing a Federal activity when providing assistance during a period of appointment into Federal service. The Administrator shall enter into annual preparedness cooperative agreements with sponsoring agencies for training, exercises, equipment acquisition, and medical monitoring. Additionally, response cooperative agreements will be established with sponsoring agencies. The Administrator will enter into response cooperative agreements with sponsoring agencies to reimburse them for costs incurred in responding to disasters or emergencies. The Administrator may incur necessary obligations to ensure the System's effectiveness and submit a report on equipment maintenance and replacement within 180 days. Conforming amendments will be made to the United States Code. Section 8101(1) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include an individual who is a System member of the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System during a period of appointment into Federal service. Additionally, Section 4303 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to include this period as part of the uniformed services for purposes of USERRA. In a technical amendment, Section 1086(d) of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2013 is modified to include provisions for System members of the National Urban Search and Rescue Response System during a period of appointment into Federal service under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The amendments made to section 1204 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 by this Act include changes to paragraph (1) and (2), specifying adjustments to effective dates and references within the text.
